Award.AwardTitle: Management and Operation of the National Center for Atmospheric Research, 2008-2018, and Supporting Activities (DTRA)

POR.DRECONTENT:
This report represents projects that are funded by the Defense Threat Reduction Agency (DTRA) and awarded through the National Science Foundation (NSF) Cooperative Agreement to the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research (UCAR) for the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR).

The nation invests heavily in technologies to defend against the accidental and intentional release of chemical, biological, radiological, and nuclear (CBRN) materials. Accurate hazard assessments for this threat rely heavily on meteorological data, atmospheric dispersion modeling tools, and the source term parameters necessary to characterize the hazard and provide warnings and situational awareness information for first responders. The primary purpose of this work was to enhance our nation's national infrastructure to respond to disasters where hazardous materials are intentionally/unintentionally released into the atmosphere. The program provided technologies that are used in national & homeland defense institutions that improve the nation's infrastructure for disaster response to CBRN incidents.

The work conducted by NCAR on this project has helped address the above pressing national security needs.  The development of advanced techniques for delivering the relevant meteorological data to the operational CBRN emergency response tools, the development of methodologies to characterize the uncertainties in the meteorological conditions used in the CBRN hazard assessments, and variational data assimilation technologies to accurately characterize the source parameters for a CBRN release have contributed to security needs . The modeling tool known as the variational iterative source term estimation (STE) algorithm (VIRSA) was delivered to the government and has been implemented into US Department of Defense (DOD) emergency response systems. NCAR has also developed a modeling framework designed to enhance the data available for CBRN defense system testing. This framework, called the Virtual Threat Response Emulation and Analysis Testbed (VTHREAT), accomplishes this task by using high fidelity atmospheric and transport and dispersion (T&D) models to generate physically realistic "single realization" CBRN material release data sets. These efforts have the dual goals of advancing our technical and scientific ability to model micro-scale processes in the atmosphere that drive technology & development, and enhance the security of our nation. The transfer of these technologies has enhanced our nation's ability to respond to intentional & unintentional releases of hazardous materials into the atmosphere.

Outreach has been accomplished by presenting the work at national conferences on atmospheric transport and dispersion modeling and through the participation in government sponsored subject matter expert working groups.  NCAR staff members  have also participated in student mentoring programs and involved students in the research. The mentoring of students provided exposure to the research and development process and experience in conducting applied research.
